Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: An Anthropological Investigation of the Legal Doctrine of Self-Determination in the Context of Decolonization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
City University of New York-Graduate Center doctoral student Mark Drury, with the guidance of Dr. Gary Wilder, will research the process and effects of applying - or attempting to apply - the legal doctrine of self-determination in the context of decolonization. This proposal examines UN-led efforts during the 1990s to hold a referendum on self-determination in the Non-Self-Governing Territory of Western Sahara. By focusing on the formation and workings of the UN mission's Identification Commission, this research will consider the significance of self-determination from the perspective of both UN planners and those who participated in the registration process, including: "identification" sheikhs tasked with authorizing or denying the oral testimony of prospective voters, government-appointed observers, and prospective voters themselves. Drury's research will contribute to understandings of how international legal concepts rely upon anthropological forms of knowledge in order to be applied in particular contexts. In addition, his attention to the failure of this particular attempt to apply self-determination will investigate the role of international law in resolving or sustaining political conflict. Where most studies focus on the limitations to international law as a problem of sovereignty and jurisdiction, this research will focus on the possibilities of, and limitations to, the legal concepts themselves.

Drury will undertake 12 months of fieldwork, splitting time between New York, Laâyoune, Western Sahara, and a Polisario-run refugee camp in Algerian territory. He will collect data through (1) interviews with former personnel involved in MINURSO, UN's mission to Western Sahara, and its Identification Commission; (2) archival research of UN documents regarding the referendum planning process; (3) semi-structured interviews and oral histories from participants from all levels of the Identification Commission process; and (4) ethnographic observations from participant observation in private and public settings.

The findings of this research will be relevant to political scientists and historians interested in the dynamics of decolonization, as well as to practitioners and scholars of political conflict and conflict resolution mechanisms. The research contributes to the training of a graduate student in anthropology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project, carried out between March 2014 and January 2016 in Moroccan-occupied Western Sahara, Morocco, Mauritania and Sahrawi-run refugee camps in Algeria, examines the complex history and geography produced by a long-running and ongoing political dispute over Western Sahara’s sovereignty. The multi-sited nature of this fieldwork involved research in disparate political contexts: an occupied territory, refugee camps, and the spaces of transit in between. Research activities varied across contexts. In Moroccan-occupied territory, a militarized urban environment under heavy surveillance made the more informal interactions typically involved in ethnographic research difficult. In Sahrawi refugee camps, research was arranged through a representative of the Sahrawi state-in-exile, and was conducted under that representative’s watchful eye. Despite the methodological challenges, extended fieldwork provided insight into figures whose widespread presence shapes the conflict’s political landscape in particular ways. One of these figures is the human rights activist, or hoqoqi; another is the returnee, or a’id. One figure draws upon the idiom of human rights in an attempt to make the struggle over sovereignty and self-determination legible and compelling to the international community; as a defector, the other in some ways rejects the terms of the conflict itself. Both raise questions about how political commitment and affiliation are produced, maintained and undermined in a longstanding political dispute defined by competing sovereignties.

In addition to examining the contemporary political geography, interviews and oral histories revealed that the political affiliations and commitments of the people in Western Sahara have been the object of considerable political contestation and struggle since decolonization began to define the horizon of political possibility in the region. This research finding suggests that returning to the 1950s is necessary for understanding the ongoing dynamics of political conflict in the region. While Sahrawi nationalism emerged in the late 1960s and took on full political force in the 1970s, the scramble to fix Saharans’ political affiliations and commitments begins a full decade earlier. By reframing this history, the problematic becomes less a matter of determining the validity of nationalism, and more about decolonization as a process that, for decades, has subjected people of the Sahara to new demands concerning their political commitments and affiliations.
